In Delusions of Grandeur, people speak of their desire for a world where the impossible is real and the impossible is possible. This is what makes their delusions powerful: they are not delusions at all but rather, they are the product of the society and culture in which they live. Delusions of Grandeur is full of people who speak in grandiloquent terms about the grandeur of their own existence, but they're not so grand that it's not clear they have a sense of self-delusion. They're just so self-important that they can't imagine they aren't the most important person in the universe.

Delusions of Grandeur is full of people who speak with authority and who seem to know exactly where they are heading. This is a book about the dangers of being too confident in your ideas. The author, Dr. Jameson Foster, has a reputation for being a brilliant and visionary scientist. In Delusions of Grandeur, people speak of the "danger of being a genius in an unstable world" and "the price of genius" as they grapple with the question of whether they can ever truly escape the grip of their own creativity and the societal expectations that come with it.
